Emanuel Cleaver, a Democratic from Missouri and chair of the Congressional Black Caucus, with us by phone from his office on Capitol Hill.
And, well, we apologize to Maya MacGuineas, the president of the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget at the New America Foundation.

Yeah, he did.

I think he did a really good job.

That's less than his own fiscal commission recommended and that's probably the least we need to do; what the fiscal commission recommended, saving about that much over a decade.
So we're going to have to do more.
Second, he's short on specifics.
If you look at what Congressman Ryan did, he put out a huge, bold plan, very detailed and very courageous, because it's hard.
You can see he's going to get beaten up for it.
The president wasn't as courageous in what he laid out there, because he didn't get specific.
But what he did do is put out something that's doable.
I think what he's talking about is a really helpful starting point for moving this discussion forward.
But just...
Third, I think...
Go ahead.

So we're going to have to move into tough territory for both parties, getting specific there.

The president talked a bit about those.
If we were to aggressively get rid of all those tax breaks, we could actually dramatically lower rates in a way that would raise revenue, to help close the deficit.
That is a pretty promising approach to all this.
We will still fight to the end, I'm sure, about taxes.

And as you look at the process, one of the curious responses you have from the public - as they've focused on these dramatic days in the past couple of weeks, as we approach a government shutdown and as all of this discussion about the long-term deficit and the debt have surged to the surfaces, people are pretty - well, I'm not sure that nauseated is too strong a word.

The problems we face - and I think the president did a good job of stating this, too - are very serious.
And this is not something that we should be looking at partisan points over.
This is something that if we don't make changes to our deficit and debt situation in advance of when credit markets force us to, we will all lose, no matter what your political point of view.
If you don't want new taxes - we hit a fiscal crisis, we will have new taxes on top of old taxes.
If you don't want to deal with reforming entitlements and a fiscal crisis hits, we will end up shredding the safety net when we don't have to.
So the point is the way to keep the economy strong is to make these changes as quickly as possible.
